Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: Novel Directions for Biological Network Alignment

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Bioinformatics research and genomic sequence alignment in particular have revolutionized the understanding of how cells work. Genomic sequence alignment identifies regions of similarity between sequences of individual genes that are a likely consequence of functional or evolutionary relationships between the sequences. However, genes and other biomolecules in the cells do not function in isolation. Instead, they interact with each other to keep one alive. And this is exactly what biological networks (BNs) model: in BNs, biomolecules are represented as nodes and physical or functional interactions between the biomolecules are represented as edges. Thus, BN alignment, which aims to identify topologically and functionally similar regions between BNs of different species, is promising to give further insights into organizational principles of life, evolution, disease, and therapeutics. For example, it could guide the transfer of biological knowledge across species between the conserved (aligned) network regions. This is important, since many nodes in BNs are currently functionally uncharacterized even for well-studied model species.

Intellectual Merit: This project aims to address several issues with the current view of the problem of network alignment. First, it will develop a novel framework for fair evaluation of existing BN alignment methods, which is currently lacking. Second, it will redefine the problem of network alignment to allow for directly optimizing the amount of conserved network topology, which current methods fail to do. Third, since different types of BNs exist that capture different functional slices of the cell, and since the existing methods can align only homogeneous networks, ignoring any node or edge types, this project will extend the proposed methods to allow for alignment of heterogeneous networks encompassing the different BN types. The proposed methods will be used in two novel interdisciplinary collaborative applications: 1) studying the role of yeast S. cerevisiae and human proteasomes responsible for protein degradation, and 2) studying pathogenicity and drug resistance of malaria parasites from the Plasmodium family.

Broader Impact: BN alignment has broad applications. For example, it can be used to transfer biological knowledge from well annotated to poorly annotated species between similar network regions or to infer species' phylogenetic and evolutionary relationships based on similarities of their BNs. Besides computational biology, this project may impact other domains as well. For example, network alignment can de-anonymize online social networks and thus impact user privacy. Since network research spans many domains, a free open-source software tool implementing the proposed methods will be offered to researchers from diverse disciplines. The software will also serve as an educational tool.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Analyses of biological networks have received significant attention. In these networks, biomolecules are represented as nodes and physical or functional interactions between the biomolecules are represented as edges. Of all network science problems, this project focused on the problem of network alignment (NA). Analogous to genomic sequence alignment, biological NA aims to find topologically and functionally similar (conserved) regions between molecular networks of different species, in order to allow for a transfer of biological knowledge from well-studied model species to poorly-studied species such as human between the conserved (aligned) network regions. This project advanced the field of biological NA via several intellectual merits, as follows.

First, it pointed out a need for a fair comparison of different NA methods and proposed a novel method evaluation framework for this purpose. Second, it redefined the problem of NA. Namely, while traditional NA methods find an alignment between networks by optimizing total similarity over all mapped nodes (called node conservation), they typically evaluate the quality of the resulting alignments with respect to the amount of edges that have been conserved under the given node mapping (called edge conservation). That is, traditional methods align similar nodes in hope to conserve many edges. Instead, this project aimed to directly optimize edge conservation while constructing alignments, resulting in several novel NA methods, including GREAT, WAVE, and MAGNA (and its successor MAGNA++).  Third, analogous to genomic sequence alignment, there exist two types of biological NA: local and global. The two NA types result in different output types, which makes their comparison hard. So, this project performed the first ever comprehensive and fair comparison of local and global NA, shockingly finding that the two are complementary: local NA results in low topological but high functional alignment quality, while global NA results in high topological but low functional alignment quality. So, the project proposed a new hybrid NA method called IGLOO that integrates algorithmic components of local and global NA to reconcile the two, i.e., to produce alignments of high topological as well as functional quality. Fourth, while traditional NA methods are homogeneous, meaning that they can deal only with a single node type and a single edge type, this project extended one of its resulting homogeneous network alignment approaches, WAVE, into its heterogeneous counterpart. This is important, because increasing amounts of different (i.e., heterogeneous) types of -omics data are becoming available, and heterogeneous approaches are needed to cope with such data. The project demonstrated the superiority of heterogeneous NA over traditional homogeneous NA.

NA has broad impacts and applications, from inferring species' phylogenetic and evolutionary relationships based on similarities of their molecular networks in the computational biology domain, to comparing online social networks with impacts on user privacy. This project used its computational methodologies to study human aging. Since human aging is hard to study experimentally due to long lifespan, aging-related knowledge needs to be transferred from well-annotated model species to poorly-annotated human. Traditionally, genomic sequence alignment has been used for this purpose. Instead, this project used NA. By doing so, it produced novel human aging-related knowledge, which complements currently available knowledge about aging that has been obtained by sequence alignment. In addition, the project resulted in interdisciplinary collaborations with biological scientists, such as inferring proteasome interaction networks of human for different biological conditions and studying topological and biological (dis)similarities between the networks by comparing them.

Since network science (and thus the NA problem) spans many domains, free open-source software implementing the NA methods resulting from this project was developed. For example, our MAGNA++ software tool provides a friendly graphical user interface for easy use by domain (e.g. biological) scientists, and at the same time, it offers source code for easy extensibility by computational scientists. Also, the developed software can serve as an education tool, in e.g., network science or computational biology courses.

This project's research was integrated with several educational activities, including research supervision of graduate and undergraduate students, and yearly career mentoring workshops for middle school girls as a part of the Expanding Your Horizons initiative.
